title: New boss at training regulator has massive job ahead
text:
"We fall down badly. We don't get the message through to schools. I'd say 'hallelujah!' if the regulator took on that job," Mr Manickam said.

The CEO of TAFE Directors Australia, which represents the government side of training, said ASQA needed to reduce comlexity in the sector which had become overwhelming.

Craig Robertson said ASQA had done a "good job" turning the sector around after VET-Fee Help but in the process training packages had become too cumbersome.

There are hundreds of thousands of specifications for courses and rules and it is just too hard for any provider to keep up. — Craig Robertson, TAFE Directors Australia

"There are hundreds of thousands of specificiations for courses and rules and it is just too hard for any provider to keep up."

"The training ministers know this but it needs someone to look at what has made the sector so complex."

But if ministers were asking ASQA to do more education there was something wrong. It shouldn't need education to show providers what was a quality product and what was not, he said.

Recently it was revealed that governments have made 465 reforms to the training sector in the last 21 years, an average of one every 2 1/2 weeks for more than two decades.

Advertisement

Jenny Lambert, director of employment, education and training at the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said the training sectors' approach to assessment needed an overhaul.

ASQA knew assessment was no where near what it should have been and had made it a priority in its recent strategy outlook.

This needed a lot of rethinking given the scale of the job and in the long run assessment of training courses and providers would probably come down to random audits or capstone reviews.

She said Mr Patterson had rescued the industry's reputation after VET-Fee Help but his organisation had become too focused on compliance.

"Quality is not just about complaince. It's about how you ensure the system continues to improve. Quality is about the standards of teachers and professionalism."

Ms Rice, who takes over as interim commissioner today, was formerly the deputy commissioner responsible for risk, intelligence and regulatory support.
description: The resignation of former chief commissioner Mark Paterson leaves a massive job for the new boss
